CatDescriptText: Mr. Raymond C. Gorham, sign painter, Sewickley and Miss Joan Rech, bookkeeper, Mount Lebanon, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, April 15, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "In dispensing political patronage jobs to various groups, what should bet eh determining factor- the financial contribution of that group to the party, or the number of votes the group casts for the party?" Mr. Raymond C. Gorham's answer reads: "It shouldn't be either of the two, but on the basis of merit...However, if a decision has to be made on the basis of one of the two, I would say the votes are the more important, because the total is the cardinal thing by which a party gets into office."  Miss Joan Rech's answer reads: "Definitely the amount of the vote should be the determining factor."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Raymond C. Gorham wearing cap and zippered jacket, standing in front of C.A. Michel, Smithfield Street, Downtown; Portrait of Joan Rech wearing dark coat and leather gloves, standing in front of C.A. Michel, Smithfield Street, Downtown
